description: Borrowed from French aperception (New Latin apperceptiō, used by Gottfried Leibnitz (1646–1716)).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, psychology and philosophy, especially Kantianism) The mind's perception of itself as the subject or actor in its own states, unifying past and present experiences; self-consciousness, perception that reflects upon itself.
(countable, psychology) The general process or a particular act of mental assimilation of new experience into the totality of one's past experience.
